According to the CDC: 
At the end of 2003, an estimated 1,039,000 to 1,185,000 persons in the United States were living with HIV/AIDS, with 24-27% undiagnosed and unaware of their HIV infection. 
 http://www.cdc.gov/hiv/stats.htm#hivest 
 If we take an average of both figures, plus the average undiagnosed percentage that comes to (1,112,000 + 25.5% =) 1,395,560 persons currently estimated to be living with HIV/AIDS.
 
 If we assume that the percentage of these who are men-who've-had-sex-with-men approximates the 45% reflected in recent diagnosed cases (an unscientific assumption, I admit, but probably in the ballpark), we're looking at roughly 628,000 current HIV/AIDS cases who could have contracted the virus from such activity.
 
 The current population of the US, according to the Census Bureau, is 296,564,210.
 
 If we take an average of the various estimates of the percentage of the population that is gay, it comes out somewhere around 5%. Assuming there are more gay men than gay women, let's assume that they comprise 3% of that 296,564,210, or 8,896,926.
 
 628,000 is 7% of 8,896,926.
 
 The horrendous effects of the HIV virus on the gay community should not be minimized or downplayed. Citizens and governments the world over must unite to do all in their power to bring an end to this rampant, virulent scourge.
 
 But characterizing 7% as "widespread" is nothing but an attempt to demonize the gay community as wanton indulgers in diseased sex, and using it to argue in favor of punishing all gay men (and gay women, who have the lowest  infection rates) is beyond specious.

 Why doesn't the black engineer living in Orlando do something about the gang violence in Detroit? The truth is, he's not part of the Detroit community at all, no more than you are. In the exact same sense, I am no more part of the gay community that spreads AIDS than you are. Simply because I happen to share a sexual orientation similar to those people doesn't mean I know who they are. It doesn't mean I know anyone with AIDS. I wouldn't even know where to find someone with AIDS if I wanted to.
 
 In reality, I only know people with AIDS by hearing things about people I never met down the grapevine, the same way you might. I'm not part of that community any more than you are. But that doesn't mean I don't work to prevent AIDS. But I only do what I know how; I try to tell my friends to behave safely, for example. Many gay rights organizations also try to prevent AIDS; I volunteer for them, and I help out in those activities. We sometimes hand out safe sex flyers and pamphlets at events.
 
 I guess my point is that even though gay and bisexual people are not always part of these communities that spread AIDS, we do often try to prevent unsafe sex. Perhaps it's true that we're doing it in part because we don't want others to generalize unsafe sex across all gay people, when most of us aren't engaging in it. But it's also true that we sympathize with and care about people suffering from the disease, even though we don't know them. So maybe I should be asking why you aren't working to prevent AIDS.

Social divisions - Sexuality
 In the early years of the epidemic, it seemed that HIV was something which predominantly affected gay men. Over the years since then, however, epidemiological patterns have gradually shifted - the majority of people currently living with HIV in America are still men who have sex with men, but in 2003, heterosexual transmission accounted for 31% of all newly-diagnosed AIDS cases - up from 3% in 198517.
 
 Men who have sex with men (MSM), however, are still at a high risk of HIV infection - in 2003 they accounted for an estimated 57% of AIDS cases amongst men and well over half of HIV diagnoses. Particularly at risk are younger MSM and MSM from racial minorities. Perhaps because their age means that they didn't see friends die in the early years of the epidemic, they are becoming increasingly complacent about practising safer sex, and remain at considerably higher risk of encountering a sexual partner who is HIV+ than members of any other group in America.
 
 Social divisions - Injecting Drug Users (IDUs)
 In addition to being seen as a 'disease of gay men', HIV has been assumed to be something which was a problem for people who injected drugs, as the early years of the epidemic saw many IDUs infected, and HIV can be easily transmitted via the sharing of infected injecting equipment. In 2003, 19% of women and 14% of men who were diagnosed HIV+ were injecting drug users who were assumed to have been infected as a result of their drug abuse18.
 
 Social divisions - Race
 Ever since the start of the epidemic in the USA, it has particularly affected racial and ethnic minorities. The demography of the epidemic has changed considerably over the last decade - from being previously an affliction of gay males, HIV has changed course, and, while gay men remain a high-risk group in America, it is now affecting disproportionate numbers of African Americans, especially women.
 
 Indeed, racial minority groups now represent almost three quarters of new AIDS cases. In 2003, African Americans accounted for 50% of all AIDS cases diagnosed during the year, even though they accounted for only 12% of the population. Among African American women, the figures are even more alarming - they represent up to 72% of all new HIV cases in American women. These high HIV figures suggest that in years to come, AIDS figures will be made up largely of African Americans.19
 
 http://www.avert.org/aids-america.htm
